question.title: JavaFX left and center aligment
question.body:
I'm trying to create a UI that has a home button on the top left and a logo image on the top center. I just can't seem to align these two objects so that they're both in the right position... Can you help me? Thanks!

<BorderPane prefHeight="720.0" prefWidth="1280.0" stylesheets="@../style/artisti_game.css" xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx/23.0.1" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1" fx:controller="it.viques.matteomusicquiz.controllers.ArtistiGameController">
   <top>
      <HBox alignment="TOP_CENTER" prefHeight="100.0" prefWidth="200.0">
         <children>
            <Button alignment="TOP_LEFT" mnemonicParsing="false" text="Button" HBox.hgrow="ALWAYS" />
            <ImageView fitHeight="150.0" fitWidth="200.0" pickOnBounds="true" preserveRatio="true">
               <image>
                  <Image url="@../images/main_logo.png" />
               </image>
            </ImageView>
         </children>
      </HBox>
   </top>
</BorderPane>

question_comments.body: @BasilBourque I don't think so; the duplicate also has an answer that uses a BorderPane. The StackPane option is in essence the same basic answer ("use a more appropriate layout pane").
@James_D & jewelsea â€” Should I re-open the Question?

As well as a BorderPane, you could also consider a StackPane here. Use StackPane.alignment="TOP_LEFT" for the button and StackPane.alignment="TOP_CENTER" for the image. The difference in behavior for the stack pane and border pane is in how they handle the scenario where there is not enough space for both child elements (stack pane will overlap them, border pane will truncate the button text and ultimately clip the button if space decreases). A BorderPane is probably better suited to your needs, but StackPane is also an option worth considering.
A BorderPane can align left/center/right and also top/bottom if that is what you want. An image that illustrates your desired layout might help for these kind of questions.

HBox has no notion of left, center, right as I recall. Look at the original Question I designated, which uses Region to create expanding gaps in between. If that does not solve your issue, flag me to re-open, after you edit the Question to explain how that does not help you.
